report_title: Oil & Gas Pipeline Construction in the US
executive_summary: The oil and gas pipeline construction has seen falling revenue since 2019. Numerous construction projects have recently centered on delivering affordable hydrocarbons from tight shale formations to global energy consumers. However, the world prices of oil and gas have been extremely volatile during the current period and have limited capital expenditure by upstream and downstream industries. The construction of new pipelines was also severely impacted by COVID-19 lockdowns, which hamstrung global demand for energy.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The United States is a global leader in climate advocacy, with most states having implemented renewable portfolio standards. These self-imposed guidelines encourage the use of clean energy within a state's power grid and have resulted in legislators becoming less willing to permit new pipeline construction.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Fossil Fuel Production Will Continue to Soar in the United States
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Exploration and production of fossil fuels will continue to rise in the United States to accommodate the globe's vast appetite for energy. The US has recently become the world's leading producer of fossil fuels.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The United States is Planning a Green Transition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The United States (and much of the rest of the world) has been instituting policies that will promote green energy over the coming years. While this has had a mixed effect on natural gas, as it produces relatively less carbon emissions than other fossil fuels, a green energy transition would ultimately require a move away from gas and oil.

industry_definition: This industry comprises contractors that are responsible for the construction of gas and oil pipelines, mains, pumping stations, refineries and storage tanks. It also includes construction management companies and special trade contractors that are primarily involved in oil and pipeline construction.

opportunities: US oil and gas production index

key_trends: Construction companies rely on establishing a reputation for completing quality work within time and budgetary constraints.
They also need to develop a network of strong relationships with oil and gas extraction, production and distribution corporations.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Construction of private gas infrastructure includes the cost of all buildings and structures which are necessary to gather, transport, store and distribute natural gas.

Public spending on hydrocarbon infrastructure includes the cost of all buildings and structures which are used to gather, transport, store and distribute crude oil and natural gas. Governments have been less willing to invest in hydrocarbon projects in recent years with focus shifting toward renewable resources.

products_and_services.product_description: New pipeline construction includes the cost of materials and the value of the installation.
Revenue from additions, alterations, renovations and reconstruction includes the cost of goods sold and installation.
This segment includes the cost to service the millions of miles of mainline and gathering lines, pumphouses and refineries that work together to bring hydrocarbons to market.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The US oil and gas production index
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The US oil and gas production index measures the change in annual crude oil and natural gas production in the United States. More infrastructure and maintenance are needed as exploration and production companies pump more oil and gas. A rising US oil and gas production index represents a potential opportunity for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Southwest is the world's largest energy hub. Texas accounts for 42.4% of total crude production and 24.6% of natural gas production in the United States, according to the Energy Information Administration (EIA). Major infrastructure projects in this region surround adding the infrastructure necessary to support growing demand for exports of oil and gas.

The Southeast has a larger population than any other region and therefore consumes a significant amount of energy. Numerous pipelines, refineries, storage facilities and distributions lines help bring oil and gas North from Texas through the Southeast. The Marcellus Formation exists in West Virginia and construction companies help transport oil and gas to markets throughout the world.

A growing number of oil and gas pipelines are being constructed to connect energy-reliant industrial and commercial customers in Michigan, Ohio and Illinois with key supplying hubs. Additionally, a growing number of pipelines are being reversed to accommodate rising production from the Bakken Formation as well as from Canada.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Downstream markets may, however, look to alternative energy sources when one is significantly more expensive. US oil and gas producers are constructing new pipelines that connect producers with export terminals.

The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) is an independent government agency that regulates the interstate transport, storage and sale of oil and natural gas by pipeline. FERC also reviews proposals to build.
FERC's role is crucial in balancing energy infrastructure development with environmental protection and community interests.

This legislation included a provision that overturned the Energy Policy Conservation Act of 1975, which banned exports of oil and gas from the United States. This opened the tap for US oil and gas to enter the global market and has led to significant investment in the construction of pipelines to key export terminals.

The Department of Transportation's Pipeline and Hazardous Material Safety Administration (PHMSA) is responsible for regulating, monitoring and enforcing safety at natural gas pipeline operations. The administration's goals are to minimize threats to individuals and the environment by all modes of transportation, including pipelines. Regulations include requirements for materials, welding, pressure testing and integrity management.
Public Utilities Commissions (PUCs) were formed by state legislatures throughout the early 1900s to regulate electric, water and gas utilities.

NEPA mandates that federal agencies assess the environmental effects of their actions, including approving pipeline projects. This involves preparing detailed Environmental Impact Statements (EIS) and Environmental Assessments (EA). NEPA promotes environmental stewardship, ensuring that projects consider ecological, social, and economic impacts before moving forward.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Lucrative contracts go to largest companies
concentration_points.concentration_description: Only a small number of construction companies have the skill and capability to tackle colossal pipeline projects that can span thousands of miles across several states.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Small companies focus on regional projects
concentration_points.concentration_description: According to the US Census Bureau's County Business Patterns survey, 54.6% of industry establishments employ fewer than 20 workers and 28.5% of establishments employ fewer than five workers. Smaller operators depend on small, regional contracts to generate revenue. These smaller contracts are typically not worthwhile for the largest operators to undertake. Smaller operators experience steady demand for their services.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Equipment and Machinery Dominate Other Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs include insurance, legal costs, poor and doubtful debts, repair and maintenance charges, equipment and machinery rental costs, professional fees, amortization, administrative costs and any other costs incurred in the industry that is not itemized elsewhere.

volatility_points.volatility_title: FLUCTUATING ENERGY COSTS IMPACT CONSTRUCTION PLANS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Exploration and production companies ramp up drilling and supply when prices are high. This drives demand for the construction of transmission, storage and distribution infrastructure to bring the more costly commodity to market.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS ARE DRIVING INNOVATION
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Pipelines are widely recognized as the safest and most cost-effective means of transporting liquids and gases over long distances. Still, inroads need to be made to improve the safety of job sites and reduce the environmental impact of essential energy infrastructure.

FAQs.question: How has your company handled volatility in crude oil and natural gas prices?
FAQs.answer: The construction of new pipelines is largely tied to periods of high energy prices, largely moving in line when capital expenditure is high. When energy prices are depressed, demand for new construction will fall off, limiting business opportunities because there is little incentive for downstream operators to contract industry services. Overall, industry demand will trend in line with the overall value of nonresidential construction, which is driven by forward-looking expectations of downstream customers.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage downside market risk?
FAQs.answer: As demand for industry projects is generally tied to energy prices, industry projects can be canceled or put on hold as future expectations change.

FAQs.question: How does your company protect against input price volatility?
FAQs.answer: Construction companies that are in proximity to key input suppliers will have reduced purchase costs and higher profitability. Furthermore, entering into long-term procurement contracts with suppliers in order to lock in rates, giving them upside protection. Construction firms located in proximity to project sites will exhibit reduced transportation costs and higher profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage price risk?
FAQs.answer: Specialized construction firms may have a given reputation in the space, boosting business opportunities. However, companies that derive most revenue from one or project types will likely exhibit overexposure to market risk. Should demand conditions decline, so too will company revenue. Contractors who operate in a variety of product segments will exhibit less volatility when demand and prices for a specific segment declines.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to reduce wage costs via technological adoption?
FAQs.answer: By automating administrative tasks via software and technology, labor resources can be redirected to more efficient tasks. The technical nature of skilled employees makes it difficult to replace these job functions with technology, however, labor costs can be lowered via the efficient subcontracting of nonessential workers and only keeping skilled, accredited employees on the books full time.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to leverage the commercialization of drone technology?
FAQs.answer: With the Federal Aviation Administration's recent ruling on commercial drone usage, drones can now be legally operated by commercial operators below a specific height limit, with no licensure required. Drones have the capability to heat-map, 3D model, and scope out job sites. All of which will save labor, increase operational efficiencies and widen profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company prepared to adapt to shifting environmental regulations?
FAQs.answer: Contractors with a penchant for environmentally-friendly construction methods may be favored by the public, boosting contract tender opportunities. Noncompliant contractors will be subject to civil fines and penalties. Furthermore, the cost of not keeping ahead of certain regulations may increase operating costs, for the time being, reducing operator efficiency and profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all occupational health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: Compliant contractors will exhibit lower premiums and insurance costs, boosting profitability. As with environmental regulation, it is better for companies to embody a strong reputation for self-regulation and low incidence on job sites. A company that prides itself on a reputation of safety can expect to win more tenders, since insurance costs will be less compared to other, perhaps more risky companies. Noncompliant contractors will be subject to higher insurance premiums and cost increases, limiting profitability.

FAQs.question: Does your company face any issues financing ongoing operations?
FAQs.answer: Due to the volatility of energy prices, some projects can be canceled or put on hold when conditions are unfavorable, limiting revenue growth. Contractors that enter into long-term maintenance contracts will have steadier cash flows.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margin compare to those of your biggest competitors?
FAQs.answer: Contractors that are able to minimize purchase and labor costs will exhibit higher operating efficiencies and wider margins. Contractors can hedge against future input price increases by entering into long-term input supply contracts, reducing purchase costs and boosting profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure it can offer the lowest tender bid? Has your ability to compete on tender affected operations?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the industry typically compete based on price and companies must be able to procure building materials at competitive rates in order to offer the best prices to be selected for tender.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage market risk? Are you able to quickly adapt to market changes?
FAQs.answer: Due to wide annual fluctuations in demand, successful operators need to be able to adapt to changing market conditions. Those who specialize in one specific segment of the industry will be exposed to downturns in that single market more so than those who offer a variety of product services to a variety of end markets.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage the retention of skilled, accredited employees? What kind of skills do you seek out in a potential workforce?
FAQs.answer: Since skilled employees command a wage premium it is critical for industry operators only to keep a minimal number of full-time employees on the books, which will limit labor costs while subcontracting less essential labor will be reflected as a purchase cost.

FAQs.question: How do levels of price and production of oil and natural gas affect your business? Do you closely track this index?
FAQs.answer: When production increases, demand for pipeline infrastructure also rises, as upstream oil companies must transport their products.

FAQs.question: How does your company keep ahead of a shifting regulatory environment? What regulations currently affect your business?
FAQs.answer: The Oil and Gas Pipeline Construction industry is heavily regulated; therefore, environmental concerns are common hurdles for industry operators.

FAQs.question: How does your company manage input cost fluctuation? Do you closely track the price of steel?
FAQs.answer: Steel is an essential input in oil and gas pipeline construction, and high steel prices place pressure on industry profit.
